title: Arbor Low Walking Route

images.title: Michael Allen / CC BY-SA (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0)
images.caption: Arbor Low in the Autumn. Not as spectacular as Stonehenge, but somewhat quieter.

images.title: Gib Hill Barrow by John M, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Gib Hill Barrow. It is thought to be a Neolithic oval barrow with an Early Bronze Age round barrow superimposed at one end. It is located some 300 metres south-west of Arbor Low henge.

images.title: Hole in the Wall by Des Blenkinsopp, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hole in the Wall between Gib Hill and Arbor Low.

images.title: Notice board at Arbor Low Henge and Stone Circle by Chris Thomas-Atkin, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Notice board at Arbor Low Henge and Stone Circle. Includes historical details of the ceremonies of the first farmers at the site.

images.title: Upper Oldhams Farm by Des Blenkinsopp, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Upper Oldhams Farm and countryside. View of this farm which is located close to the site.

description:
Visit this Neolithic henge monument and enjoy some lovely moorland scenery on this fascinating circular walk in the Peak District. The site is located a few miles west of Youlgreave . You can park at Upper Oldhams Farm just off Long Rake. Walk through the farm (there is a £1 charge per person) and then climb towards Arbor Low. The limestone circle sits in an elevated position with super views over the White Peak area of the Peak District. The henge is one of the most well preserved in Britain with 50 large limestone slabs and fragments. It's an atmospheric place, thought to date back to 2500BC to 1500 BC. After you have explored the stone circle you can head south west to Gib Hill where you will find an ancient burial mound. The High Peak Trail and the Midshires Way both pass close to the site at Parsley Hay.
You could pick up these long distance footpaths to extend your walking in the area. Heading north west will take you to Pomeroy while heading south takes you towards Hartington and the Biggin Dale Nature Reserve. Just over a mile to the north you'll find the beautiful Lathkill Dale . This is a great place to extend your walking in the White Peak. There are wonderful limestone cliffs and the rushing waters of the River Lathkill to enjoy.
